title: Common Public Domain Misconceptions
description: Addressing common myths and misunderstandings about public domain

myths.myth: If it's on the internet, it's in the public domain
myths.reality: Most online content is still protected by copyright unless explicitly stated otherwise
myths.explanation: The internet is not a public domain repository. Copyright protection extends to digital works just as it does to physical ones.

myths.myth: Public domain means I can use a work without attribution
myths.reality: While not legally required in most cases, ethical attribution is still recommended
myths.explanation: Attribution is often expected in academic, professional, and cultural contexts even for public domain works.

myths.myth: Public domain works can't be sold
myths.reality: Public domain works can be freely used, including for commercial purposes
myths.explanation: The work itself is free, but you can still charge for value-added services or formats.

myths.reality: Copyright terms vary by country, so a work may be PD in some countries but not others
myths.explanation: Always check the copyright status in your specific jurisdiction before use.

myths.myth: Public domain means the same as free or open source
myths.reality: Public domain is different from licensed free content
myths.explanation: Public domain means copyright has expired or been forfeited; free licenses still have copyright holders.
